reviewText:
This has got to be... The best game I've ever played!
How have I gone without playing this game before?
I am just speechless at how magnificent this game is.
Sometimes, this game haunts my dreams with its beauty.

Generally, I refrain from reviewing games.
As you may have noticed however, I MUST review this gem.
My life would be incomplete without the Vigil Experience(tm).
Every time I view the game in my library, I tear up a little.

So, for those of you wanting to buy this game, I leave you this:
Usually, take any review you read with a grain of salt.
Carefully read between the lines each for review, even this one.
Keep in mind, I'm not recommending this game.
Sorry reader, but read the first letter of every line.

reviewText: This game definetly is.... Unique for sure. No other game quite has the gameplay or graphical stylings that this does. However it soon becomes apparent WHY no other game has these. The camera often hides vital gameplay elements or vital elements are obscured by other similar looking black and white pieces. The controls are confusing and just buggy, the story is... somewhere. No idea where but wherever it is, its consuming a large amount of LSD.\n\nJust avoid.

reviewText:
Well what can I say about this game?

Lets start on how to run it:
Compatability to XP/2k, play now in steam, that will take you to RIP-Trilogy" page.  Hit the download demo button (even if like me you already own the full version).  Don't download
date:
just keep the pop-up up. Hit play now again and there you go.  Hit ALT + Enter when it locks up.  If you hit F12 for a printscreen it will lock up.

Now the good:
It's usually free in a bundle
It's weird and abstract looking
When it runs ... it runs.

The bad:
Hard to get to run
Crappy controls
Good concept
recommended:

reviewText: Avoid... it's garbage. Look up a playthrough of it, you'll see you're not missing much for not being able to purchase it. reviewText: I like unique and creative games, and that is certainly what this game wants to be, but it falls short on every level.  The art style is so abstract that it is very difficult to understand what you're looking at, especially as the camera changes to extremely unusable angles with each new room.  The voices and sound effects are just painful to hear.  Beyond presentation, the game progression is completely arbitrary.  Randomly clicking around is your best way to determine what actions are even available to you.  There are game segments which want to be puzzles, without any indication of your goal or the pieces.  Finally, the story is ridiculous, less than one dimensional, and completely unrelatable in any way.  I hate to talk poorly about a unique game, but this one has earned it.

reviewText:
Vigil: Blood Bitterness combines a unique art style for gaming with some interesting sounds and wraps it around a bizarre story. Although it is a simple point-and-click adventure at heart, it is far from being intuitive.

I ended up getting frustrated to the point where I just went to YouTube and watched the entire story instead of playing it myself. The whole game can be completed in about 30 minutes and I didn't feel like I missed out on anything by simply watching it unfold.

The most annoying thing is that there is a known issue on Windows Vista & 7 systems where you are only able to see the videos when the game is in windowed mode. This would be fine if the game didn't force fullscreen every time you exited to the menu or returned to the game.

It's weird, but there's nothing here that I can really recommend. As part of the Puzzle Indie Pack on Steam, it is a great freebie" considering all the other games in the bundle are decent."

reviewText:
This is ridiculous.
Let's begin with starting the game:
You launch it, and instead of showing up, the game will take you to the Steam Shop site of RIP - Trilogy.
A short research told me, that I have to install the demo of RIP.
Luckily, it's enough to click on the download button and then cancel it immedatlely.

Once the game is started, I had a black screen and some noises, then a screen showed up where I had to choose between three 4:3 resolutions.
Once done, the game starts: Another black screen with weird noises about a minute long this time.
After that I was finally in controll. After clicking the first clickable thing: Black screen, weird noises.

Okay then, another quick research.
The black screens are supposed to show videos. Since they seem to only play in windowed mode, you have to activate it manually via alt + enter, since there is no option for it.
That fixes another bug too: The subtitles only show in windowed mode.

So I finally began to play, noticing that the window goes to fullscreen again very often, so I missed still a few cutscenes without anythingI could do about it.
After few minutes of this frustrating gameplay: Random death.

Or at least it seemed random.
After I died three times in about 20 minutes, without being able to tell why, everytime starting from the beginning of the act, I managed to progress a bit more through this black and white nightmare.

Then it happend again. Automatic switch to fullscreen, so I switched back to windowed mode. Only this time, my surroundings disappeard, leaving me with only my character visible.
A little bit confused, I tried to click on the ground around him: Death animation.

At this point, I just couldn't bring me to play anymore and uninstalled it.

0 out of 10 points for this pile of garbage.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is quite weird from my personal experience, and I didn't really get much to go on but it's fairly straight forward as is. I would not recommend this game if your not on Windows XP/2000. Reasoning for this is, I guess this game is probably a pretty old engine 2000 based game? (Idk) So due to this running on Windows 7 for example your going to notice you won't be able to run in fullscreen, you only have 3 resolution options, and 9/10 for a avg screen,it's not going to really fit.. especially if you have a big gamer screen. This game will attempt to run fullscreen despite this and you have to ALT+ENTER to force Window the game,this will require repeating every time you reach the next 'Act'. As a modern gamer, I don't really like this game at all. I never finished this game fullthrough,I got to Act 2 and apparently fell off the map and 'Game Over', not really interested in pursuing the game further. The second and major thing about this game (May be just for people not on XP/2000) is that on first-launch it will redirect to RIP Trilogy 3 Store Page,it requires you to own the game and or demo. Sure the game demo is 30MB,small, but the principal of it is quite surprising,why do I need to have your other game just to play a game of yours I already purchased? (Or at least 'try' your other game). From what I've read online this game appears to be pretty short, I can't really confirm since I never finished but I'm never going too, not interested.

reviewText: There are times when Metacritic gets it wrong, and this is most definitely one of those times.  A score of 61 would put this game in the Meh
hoursPlayed: that decimal point needs to go about 1 or 2 places to the left.  Even a score of 10 should have triggered a federal investigation of payola over at Metacritic.\n\nThe game's one novel feature
voteText: the developer's apparent tweaking of the Dark Engine's texture filters until only black and white remains
helpfulPercent: is a one-trick pony that wears out its welcome within minutes
votesTotal: wince-inducingly annoying.\n\nGameplay is nothing more than an exercise in frustration
votesFunny: as clues are cryptic without being logical
commentsCount: solutions are arbitrary and often linked to timers tuned so short that anything less than following the developer's intended path and timing
column16: without an  angstrom's width of deviation
column17: will result in certain death and banishment back to the last checkpoint.  Bugs are game-breaking and interspersed with the wonky puzzles in such a way that there is no way to tell if you are simply approaching the puzzle "incorrectly"
column18: or if the game has broken itself in such a way to make the puzzle unsolveable.\n\nI had played through a section with a long walkway outside and "airlocks" at each end.  If you remained outside on the walkway
column20: suggesting vacuum outside.  If you didn't open
column23: you died.  If you ran through
column25: BUT didn't run far ENOUGH into the next room
column26: you died (That's right: if you did it correctly
column27: and were standing inside the safe room -- but too close to the CLOSED airlock -- you died).  If you ran through
column29: ran far enough into the next room
column30: BUT didn't do it quickly enough
column31: you died.  Fine.  Except that a few puzzles later
column33: one could now stand anywhere on the outside walkway indefinitely.  The airlocks were now open and inoperable
column34: presumably because that section was now "solved" and no longer necessary.  So
column36: just suddenly no more vacuum of space?  But as soon as I stepped through the inoperable airlock into the next room
column37: I was immediately killed by asphyxiation
column38: judging from the death cutscene -- a cutscene by now in furiatingly familiar to me in this area.\n\nFinally
column40: I looked up the solution on YouTube
column41: only to find that I had done everything correctly
column42: but the game had jiggered itself up so completely that it was now  impossible to "solve" and progress.\n\nI generally make a strong effort to complete every game I begin
column43: but this game had played me like a cheerleader plays a nerd on prom night
column44: and I had had enough.  I never went back.  I swear
column45: as I clicked "Delete local content" I heard myself let out an evil little giggle.\n\nSo don't do it.  Just don't.  Browse away from this page and never return.  If I can save just one of you from the torture that I endured trapped inside this ♥♥♥♥ of a game

column49: that could've been me".  Now go."

reviewText: I only got this game as it was part of a puzzle pack with 3 other games on sale for a buck. This is the type of game that makes me regret spending the 25 cents that went toward this game. As other reviewers have noted, frequent crashes, awful and jagged graphics, iffy controls, and a multitude of other problems plague this game.\n\nVigil: Blood Bitterness would have gotten a C+ as a college project. As a published game that someone is expected to pay money for? 0.5 out of 10. I give it that much for the interesting color pallete and I thought the blur in the menus were an interesting touch. Other than that, I've had better gaming experiences in the loading screens of other games.

reviewText:
Don't touch this broken, buggy, game even if you get it for free. You'll only regret the wasted time downloading it and the hdd space it's taking up!

The game glitched when it was first installed some time ago, poor controls, cut-scenes not visible giving the impression the game has crashed amongst other things. Since then another damned great glitch has turned it into an expensive shortcut to the RIP - Trio page!!!

Don't know whether to blame Steam (for selling it), Meridian4 (for publishing it) or Freegamer (for developing it). Think I'll go for Freegamer, their homesite is nothing more than a facebook page! Should never have trusted somebody whose address is the digital equivalent of a p.o. box!

reviewText:
After playing this there is a great amount of bitterness running through my veins, so I guess it lived up to it's name in that respect.

I played this game to see if the reviews were exaggerating (I got one of those Puzzle Indie Pack coupons), so the first thing I will say is: They were not exaggerating. Not at all.

I'm not entirely sure what to say, like as with the other reviews the design idea seemed cool. Y'know until you actually put it into practice and realise that walls and doors and open spaces are basically the same colour: black (yay!). The cutscenes for me were broken, so I was probably more confused than most of the already confused people playing this (or less, you never know). The movement is awkward, the camera angles were frustrating...I think what I'm trying to get out is this game was so confusing and so poorly designed that it felt like less of a game and more of a chore.

reviewText: Steer clear!  First off, this game will not run properly on Windows 7, and I'm guessing Windows 8.  You have to run it in compatibility mode and it still doesn't work correctly.  In addition, the game tries to force you to install the demo for another game before you can run it.  You can trick it, but this is still extremely shady.  After you finally get it running it's just confusing and barely playable due to many graphical erros and hiccups.  Avoid it completely, even if like me you were suckered into buying it in a bundle.
